School of Environmental and Municipal Engineering, Xi’an University of Architecture and Technology Yanta Road 13# Xi’an China Adding polyethylene glycol (PEG) can lessen the shedding of coating and improve the dispersion of active particles for monolithic catalysts. In this study, a series of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P x )/TiO2(P x )/CH catalysts were prepared with different PEG molecular weights (P x , x = 200, 1000, and 2000) to explore the effect of P x addition on the structure and activity of the catalysts in microwave catalytic combustion of toluene. The research showed that P x addition (1 wt% dosage to titanium sol) to coating reduced the particle size of titanium sol and decreased the shedding rate of TiO2 coating 0.9–0.93 %, and P x addition (3 wt% dosage to CH's water absorption) to active components further lessened the shedding rate of the catalysts 1.93–2.04 %. Under an initial toluene concentration of 1500 mg/m3 and a gas hourly space velocity of 2260 h−1, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH owned the highest catalytic activity and its complete removal temperature (TR100) and mineralization temperature (TM100) to toluene were 180℃ and 218℃, respectively, which were lower 33℃ and 16℃, 56℃ and 58℃ than Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH catalysts separately, and its activity maintained steadily with toluene removal efficiencies of 99–91 % over 12 h. The improved activity is attributed to the uniform dispersion of active particles, larger specific surface area, and increased adsorbed oxygen, facilitated by pore-forming and steric-hindrance effects of P x . Electron transfer among Mn4+/Mn3+/Mn2+, Cu2+/Cu+, and Ce4+/Ce3+ promoted the oxidation of toluene under microwave irradiation. Therefore, the research provides technological support for developing transition metals-based catalysts for industrial VOC waste gas treatment. Graphical Abstract Keywords Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH catalyst Polyethylene glycol Pore-forming effect Microwave catalytic combustion Toluene Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As China's industrialization progresses rapidly, the amounts of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) that are discharged from the plants increase fast, and most VOCs are irritating, toxic, and even carcinogenic, and the main culprits of photochemical smog, acid rain, ozone layer destruction [1,2]. Therefore, VOCs have caused health risks, environmental pollution, and ecological destruction. Catalytic combustion, as one end-of-pipe technology, can efficiently treat industrial VOC waste gas and be widely adopted by companies in developing countries [3–5], and the monolithic catalyst plays a crucial role in the technical process. The monolithic catalyst commonly comprises carrier, coating, and active components. Honeycombed carriers, like cordierite honeycomb (CH), are widely applied as the carriers of industrial catalysts and have the advantages of small pressure drop, rapid heat and mass transfer rates, excellent thermo stability, and good mechanical strength [6] to ensure a fluent pass of the waste gas. However, its small specific surface area hinders active component adhesion and uniform distribution. Coating, such as γ-Al2O3 [7], TiO2, and SiO2, can significantly increase the specific surface area of the carrier to improve the dispersion of active particles and effectively increase the number of active sites. Furthermore, other coating materials like CeO2, ZrO2 [8], and Co3O4 not only improve the specific surface area of the carrier but also act as the active component to enhance the activity of the catalyst. To be mentioned, a firm adhesion and a uniform distribution of the coating on porous channels of the carrier are crucial to preparing highly active catalysts. Polyethylene glycol (PEG) was used as the adhesive to functionalize Fe3O4@MIL-101(Cr) catalyst and effectively improved the specific surface area and dispersibility of the materials [9]. Guo et al. [10]applied silica sol as the binder to prepare MoSi2-SiC-Al2O3-SiO2 coating on fibrous mullite insulation and confirmed that the coating remained intact without peeling and spalling after thermal shock tests. However, the name, dosage, and effect of the binder added to the coating were few reported due to patent protection and technological security. Similarly, for active components, whether noble metals or transition metals, their adhesion and uniform dispersion are both key to the catalyst, and the usage and amount of the agglomerate are few introduced considering of technical secret. Karami et al. [11] applied PEG15000 adhered and reduced Dimeric NC palladacycle and found that Pd/PEG15000 catalyst owned Pd nanoparticles with 2–12 nm sizes had negligible leaching of Pd during the Heck reaction. Tao et al. [12] added silica sol as the adhesive to the impregnation solution of active components but did not introduce its usage in the paper for the same reason. Presently, monolithic noble metal catalysts are widely applied in the treatment of real industrial VOC waste gas due to highly catalytic activity and low reaction temperature [13]. However, their high cost and susceptibility to chlorine and sulfur poisoning have spurred the search for alternative catalysts in recent decades. Composite transition metal catalysts exhibit several advantages, including low cost, stable catalytic activity, and excellent chlorine resistance [14]; nevertheless, their catalytic activities should be further improved to become possible alternatives of noble metal catalysts. Interestingly, certain transition metal oxides, such as manganese oxides and their composite metal oxides, can strongly absorb microwave energy, creating "high-temperature hot spots" on the catalyst surface [15], which is incredibly beneficial to the oxidation of VOCs and can significantly enhance the activity of the catalyst [16,17]. This work developed monolithic microwave-absorbing catalysts using commercial CH as the carrier, TiO2 as the coating, and Cu-Mn-Ce composite metal oxides (Cu-Mn-Ce-O x ) as the active components. The TiO2 coating was prepared using the sol-gel method and the active components were loaded using the equivalent-volume impregnation method. PEGs with different molecular weights were added and compared during the coating preparation and the loading of active components, respectively, to investigate the effect on the adhesion of the coating and the dispersion of the active components. The microwave-absorbing ability, catalytic activity, and structural change of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH catalysts after the addition of PEGs were all checked in microwave catalytic combustion of toluene, and the degradation mechanism of toluene under microwave irradiation was also speculated in the paper. The research work should lay a theoretical foundation for preparing highly active and low-cost transitional metal-based catalysts that become possible alternatives for noble metal catalysts in the future. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemical reagents and materials Copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O), Manganese nitrate (Mn(NO3)2, 50 wt% in H2O), and PEG x (x refers to the molecular weight of 200, 1000, and 2000 separately, abbreviated as P x or substituted by P200, P1000, and P2000 separately) were obtained from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Factory, China. Cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O) was sourced from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Science & Technology Co. Ltd., China. Tetrabutyl titanate, acetylacetone (C5H8O2), and toluene (C7H8) were acquired from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., China. Tributyl phosphate was purchased from Wuxi Zhanwang Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., China. Nitric acid (65 %-68 % purity) and anhydrous ethanol were obtained from Guangdong Guanghua Technology Co. Ltd., China, and Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co. Ltd., China, respectively. All chemicals were of analytical grade and were utilized directly in the experiment. The ultra-pure water was procured using the Millipore Ultra-Pure Water System. Commercial CH cubes, 100 mm × 100 mm × 50 mm with a square pore size of 1 mm, were purchased from Cangzhou Hecheng Environmental Protection Equipment Co. Ltd., China. 2.2 Preparation and characterization of the catalyst The cubic CH was cut into cylinders with a diameter of 26 mm and a height of 50 mm. The cylinders were ultrasonically washed to remove surface dust and soaked in ultrapure water for 8 h to determine their water absorption rate by weight measurement. Then, the CH carriers were washed with dilute nitric acid (10 % purity) to remove impurities from the channels and surface Mg2+ and Al3+ ions. A titanium sol was prepared with a molar ratio of 1: 18: 2: 0.5 to tetrabutyl titanate: anhydrous ethanol: ultrapure water: acetylacetone, and the pH of the sol was adjusted to 1–2 by titrated nitric acid. Subsequently, a given dosage (1 wt% to the titanium sol) of P x (x = 200, 1000, 2000 separately) was added to the sol, then stirred for 2 h, and then aged for 24 h to obtain the stabilized titanium sol. Furthermore, the CH carrier was immersed in the sol for 30 min under ultrasonic oscillation, then dried naturally at room temperature for 30 min, and then dried at 120℃ for 30 min in an oven, then calcined at 500℃ for 2 h in a muffle furnace. Finally, the 5 wt% TiO2(P x ) coating that adhered to the CH carrier was obtained by three times repeated impregnation-calcination process. For the active component loading, Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O, Mn(NO3)2, and Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O were dissolved in ultrapure water with P x (3 wt% dosage to the CH's water absorption) under ultrasonic oscillation. The mass ratio of Cu to the CH carrier was 3.25 %, and the mass ratio of Cu: Mn: Ce was 3: 3: 1, which was optimized for VOCs degradation in our previous study [18]. Some drops of tributyl phosphate were added to the solution to eliminate the foam while stirring. Subsequently, the TiO2(P x )/CH carrier was immersed into the solution under ultrasonic oscillation and flipped over manually until the solution was entirely absorbed by an equal volume impregnation method based on the water absorption of the CH carrier, guaranteeing active components adhered more uniformly onto the surface and channels of the carrier. Then, the sample was dried at 80°C overnight and calcined at 450°C for 5 h. Finally, a monolithic Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P x )/TiO2(P x )/CH catalyst was obtained after natural cooling. Under the same process, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P x )/CH catalysts were prepared without P x addition and with only P x addition into the coating, respectively. The surface morphology, pore structure, and active particle size and distribution of the catalysts were examined by a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Quanta FEG 250). All samples were pretreated at 120℃ for 2 h, and then the specific surface area and pore parameters were determined using a V-Sorb X800 instrument (BET). The crystal composition and grain size of active components were determined by an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, D8 ADVANCE, Bruker, K-Alpha). The valence states and amounts of different metal elements were measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, TSFE 250Xi, Thermo Fisher, K-Alpha) with an operating voltage of 12 kV, current of 6 mA, and vacuum pressure below 10−9 mBar. 2.3 Experimental scheme The experimental device in microwave catalytic combustion of toluene consists of three parts: intake system, catalytic combustion system, and waste gas absorption system (seen in Fig. 1). Firstly, the air orderly passed through the silica gel column and activated carbon column to remove moisture and organic impurities, respectively, and was quantified by a gas flowmeter. Then, toluene liquid was injected into a three-necked flask by a syringe pump and vaporized by an electric heating mantle. The purified air carried gaseous toluene into a mixing bottle to blend entirely before entered into the microwave catalytic combustion system, which consists of a microwave generator, fixed-bed quartz reactor (inner diameter 28 mm) that is filled by two monolithic catalysts, and temperature-measuring device. The gaseous toluene was oxidized and mineralized on the catalyst's surface under continuous microwave irradiation, and bed temperature was monitored by a thermocouple probe that was inserted into the honeycomb channel of the catalyst during the reaction process. Gas sampling sites were set up in the front and back of the quartz tube to determine the variations of toluene and CO2 concentrations to calculate toluene removal and mineralization rates, respectively. Finally, the treated waste gas was orderly absorbed by methanol and NaOH solution before being discharged into the air. In this study, the zeta potential, particle size, and viscosity of titanium sol were firstly measured by a zeta potential meter (ZS90, Malvern Instruments LTD, UK) and a viscometer (LVDV, Brookfield, Germany), respectively, to optimize sol particle size, dispersion and adhesion under the addition of different P x . Then, the temperature-rising curves of the catalysts were investigated under microwave irradiation at a power of 80 W. The catalytic activities and stabilities of the catalysts were checked by microwave catalytic combustion of toluene under conditions of an initial toluene concentration (C0) of 1500 mg/m³ , air flow of 0.12 m3/h and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 2260 h−1. Then, the effect of P x addition on the catalysts' shedding rate was discussed. Finally, a theoretical explanation for the degradation mechanism in microwave catalytic combustion of toluene was concluded based on the experimental results and various characterizations, including SEM, BET, XRD, and XPS. 2.4 Analytical methods Toluene and CO2 concentrations at the inlet and outlet of the reactor were determined by a gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (GC6890N, Agilent, USA) and a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR, Nicolet Antares IGS, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA), respectively. The toluene removal efficiency (η, %) and mineralization efficiency (K, %) are calculated using the equations of (1) and (2) [19]. (1) η = C 0 − C C 0 × 100 % jlvWhere C0 and C represent the inlet and outlet toluene concentrations, mg/m³ , respectively. (2) K = ( P out − P in ) × 92 7 × 44 × C 0 × 100 % Where Pin and Pout represent the CO2 concentration at the inlet and outlet, mg/m³ , respectively. 92, 44, and 7 are toluene molecular weight, CO2 molecular weight, and mole number of carbon in toluene separately. The catalyst's shedding rate was determined by the gravimetric method under 30 min of ultrasonic oscillation at a power of 80 W. In this study, the catalyst activity test was repeated twice, and the given data was the mean value to eliminate an operation error. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Px addition in TiO2 coating This study examined the titanium sol-gel system's zeta potential and particle size and the loading and shedding rates of TiO2 coating on the CH carrier under different P x additions. It could be seen in Fig. 2(a) that the zeta potential increased and the particle size reduced significantly after P x addition, and the highest zeta potential and the lowest particle size reached simultaneously under P1000 addition and were 45.3 mV and 419.3 μm, respectively. The viscosity values of four titanium sols without binder and with the addition of P200, P1000, and P2000 separately were measured to be 0.36–0.39 cP, 0.62–0.65 cP, 1.08–1.11 cP, and 1.72–1.75 cP successively. Based on DLVO (named by Derjaguin, Landau, Verwey, and Overbeek four scientists) theory, it could be explained that P x adsorbed on the surface of sol particles to impede the charged particles' flow so that the repulsive force among the sol ions increased, that effectively improving the zeta potential value and the stability of the sol. Furthermore, P x addition increased inter-particle interaction to enhance the dispersibility of titanium sol, resulting in a decrease in particle size. However, the molecular chain of the binder becomes longer with the increase of molecular weight, which lessens the repulsive force among the sol ions so that the sol's zeta potential decreases to 34.3 mV for P2000 addition. Moreover, the decrease of the zeta potential could reduce the sol stability and increase the agglomeration possibility of the particles, which caused an increase in particle size for the addition of the binder with a bigger molecular weight. Therefore, P1000 was confirmed to be the optimal binder in Fig. 2(a) to obtain the smallest particle size of titanium sol during TiO2 coating preparation. It could be seen in Fig. 2(b) that the loading rate of TiO2 coating without P x addition was lower than that of those with P x addition, but the highest shedding rate of 1.40 % was determined for the TiO2 coating without P x addition. It indicated that P x addition improved the bonding force between the coating and the carrier, which is beneficial to the adhesion of the coating and effectively prevents its shedding from the carrier. The oxygen vinyl group of P x could combine with the hydroxyl group on the sol particles' surface to form hydrogen bonding that increases the cross-linking among the sol particles to enhance the sol viscosity. With the increase of molecular weight of the binder, the shedding rates of the coating were 0.50 %, 0.47 %, and 0.47 % for TiO2(P200), TiO2(P1000), and TiO2(P2000) separately. The influence of P x molecular weight was minor to the shedding rate of the coating. It could be attributed to the polyoxyethylene chain, curled configuration, and the interaction between the sol-gel particles [20]. In Fig. 2(b), the coating loading reached 5 wt% steadily after adding P1000 or P2000, which plays a vital role in titanium sol's stability, dispersion, and adhesion. Both P1000 and P2000 actively enhance adhesion and reduce shedding. Based on the analysis for Fig. 2, 1000 is the best molecular weight of P x that added to titanium sol as the binder to acquire the smallest TiO2 particle, steady loading rate, and the lowest shedding rate of the coating in this study. 3.2 Effect of Px addition on catalyst characteristics In this study, the temperature-rising curves of eight catalysts, such as Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P200)/CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P2000)/CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P200)/ TiO2(P1000)/CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH, and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P2000)/ TiO2(P1000)/CH, were determined under microwave irradiation to check the effects of TiO2 coating and different P x addition on the microwave-absorbing abilities of the catalysts, and the results were shown in Fig. 3(a). It showed that eight catalysts all exhibited robust microwave-absorbing characteristics due to an excellent microwave-absorbing property of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x active components [12], and their surface temperatures reached 307℃, 287℃, 321℃, 349℃, 334℃, 263℃, 330℃, and 281℃ orderly after 30 min irradiation. Compared with Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /CH, the microwave-absorbing ability of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH decreased a little due to a weaker microwave-absorbing property and good heat dissipation of TiO2 coating. However, P x addition in TiO2 coating apparently improved the microwave-absorbing capacities of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P200)/CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH, and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P2000)/CH while comparing with Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH, which is speculated that more pore structure of TiO2 coating and smaller particle size and more uniform distribution of active components (seen in latter SEM images) after P x addition could be main reasons that generating more microwave-absorbing sites on the surface of the catalysts. Furthermore, the microwave-absorbing abilities of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P200)/TiO2(P1000)/CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH, and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P2000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH were clearly weaker than that of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH, and P x addition during the loading of active components can block the hole of the coating and cause uneven distribution of active particles on the catalysts' surface (Seen in Fig. 4), especially for P200 and P2000, respectively. Reducing microwave-absorbing sites should be the main reason for a slow temperature-rising speed. It was also found that the catalysts' microwave-absorbing abilities after adding different P x to the coating or active components were in the same order of P1000 > P2000 > P200. P1000 addition can effectively enhance the microwave-absorbing ability of the catalyst, especially for the TiO2 coating. Fig. 3(b, c) showed that all five catalysts completely degraded and mineralized toluene at below 240℃ and 280℃, respectively. The activity sequence of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH > Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P2000)/CH > Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P200)/CH ≈ Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH > Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /CH was abserved for toluene removal, and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH > Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P2000)/CH > Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH > Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P200)/ CH ≈ Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /CH for toluene mineralization. The effect of TiO2 coating on catalytic activity was a little, but P x addition in the coating had a positive effect on catalytic activity, and an influence order of P x was P1000 > P2000 > P200. The complete removal temperature (TR100) and mineralization temperature (TM100) of toluene by Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH were 213℃ and 234℃, respectively, which were lower of 23℃ and 42℃ successively than those by Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH. TM100 was higher than TR100 in Fig. 3(b, c) for all five catalysts, which indicated that course products were produced in the process of toluene oxidation and further oxidized to CO2 and H2O within the temperature range of TR100 to TM100. In Fig. 3(d, e), the influence order of P x on catalytic activity was also P1000 > P2000 > P200 while added to active components, and TR100 and TM100 values of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P2000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH, and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P200)/TiO2(P1000)/CH catalysts to toluene were 180℃ and 218℃, 207℃ and 223℃, and 217℃ and 258℃ separately. Compared with Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH catalyst, P1000 and P2000 addition to active components had positive effects on catalytic activity. However, the P200 addition had a negative effect on the catalyst's activity. It is speculated to be related to the changes in coating morphology and active particle distribution. Therefore, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000) /TiO2(P1000)/CH catalyst exhibited the best activity in microwave catalytic combustion of toluene among eight catalysts, and P1000 addition in both TiO2 coating and active components obviously improved the catalytic activity in this study. However, the microwave-absorbing ability of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH catalyst was weaker than Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH catalyst in Fig. 3(a), which indicates that microwave-absorbing ability could not necessarily correlate positively with catalytic activity that also confirmed by Zhao et al. [21]. The catalytic activity of the catalyst should be a comprehensive result of many factors, including microwave-absorbing ability, size and distribution of active particles, crystal types and facets, and valence states of metal oxides. As a binder, P x addition can boost the interaction between TiO2 coating and CH carrier and improve the active particles' adhesion on the surface of the catalyst. It can be seen in Table 1 that TiO2 coating effectively decreased the catalyst's shedding rate from 6.55 % to 3.66 %, and P x addition in the coating further decreased the shedding rate of the catalyst. Furthermore, different P x addition to active components much more decreased the shedding rate to 0.30 %, 0.23 %, and 0.19 % for Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P200)/TiO2(P1000)/CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH, and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P2000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH separately. The larger the molecular weight of P x that is added to whether TiO2 coating or active components, the more viscidity of the sol or the impregnation solution, resulting in the stronger firmness of the catalyst. The strengthening of P x on the TiO2 coating was confirmed in Fig. 2(b), and the change of the catalysts' specific surface area, the pore-forming effect of P x on the coating, and active particles' dispersion into the holes on the catalysts' surface might be main reasons for the decrease of the catalysts' shedding rates. 3.3 Catalyst characterization 3.3.1 SEM The surface morphologies of eight catalysts and different elements distribution onto the Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH catalyst's surface were determined and seen in Fig. 4. Lots of irregularly active particles uniformly dispersed onto the uneven and porous CH surface (Fig. 4(a)), and TiO2 coating was fissured and active particles with larger size unevenly distributed on the TiO2 nanoparticles' surface, holes, and crackings (Fig. 4(b)). Larger active particles mean a reduction of microwave-absorbing sites, which can explain a weaker temperature-rising property for Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH than Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /CH in Fig. 3(a), and also reduce the contact time on the catalyst's surface but TiO2 adsorption (Seen in latter BET characterization) can enhance the reaction opportunities for adsorbed toluene and oxygen that resulting in similar catalytic activities for two catalysts in Fig. 3(b, c). It could be seen in Fig. 4(c-e) that much more pores and holes appeared on the catalysts' surface after P x addition in the coating, and active particles' size was smaller than that in Fig. 4(b), and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x particles evenly dispersed on the surface of the catalysts. P x can be pyrolyzed and escaped from the sol during calcination to form pores on the coating's surface, and its chemical adsorption and pore-forming effect [22] are beneficial to active particles' adhesion and dispersion that improving the microwave-absorbing ability and catalytic activity of the catalysts, especially after P1000 or P2000 addition, and reducing the shedding rates due to the cross-linking effect of P x . After adding different P x to active components, it could be seen in Fig. 4(f-h) that smaller active particles appeared on the catalysts' surface due to the chemical adsorption and steric-hindrance effect of P x [20]. The coating and pore-forming effect of P x were observed simultaneously in the figures, and more accidented surface appeared for Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH in Fig. 4(g) that is beneficial to toluene adsorption and contact with active particles. Active metal elements were distributed mostly on the surface of the catalyst in the Fig. 4(i), and the contents of Cu, Mn, and Ce were determined to be 40.79 %, 40.95 %, and 17.32 % separately, which is consistent with their loading amount, and the lowest content of Ti (0.94 %) was due to the hindrance of active particles that loaded onto the TiO2 coating. Furthermore, Cu and Ce were dispersed uniformly on the upper surface, and Mn and Ti were below them which can be seen in the Fig. 4(j-m). The water solubility is Mn(NO3)2 (139 g/100 mL at 20℃) > Cu(NO3)2 (125 g/100 mL at 20℃) > Ce(NO3)3 (60 g/100 mL at 20℃). Therefore, Mn was firstly loaded on the surface of TiO2 coating, and Cu and Ce were impregnated subsequently on the TiO2 coating's surface during the catalyst preparation. 3.3.2 BET It can be seen in Table 2 that TiO2 coating increased the specific surface area and total pore volume of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH nearly 50 % that compared with those of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /CH due to its high specific surface area and pore volume, and the decrease of average pore size from 16.57 nm to 10.64 nm could be mainly attributed to the filling of TiO2 particles into the pores of cordierite. Different P x addition to TiO2 coating further increased the specific surface area of three catalysts while comparing with Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH due to the pore-forming effect of P x , and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH catalyst had the highest specific surface area and total pore volume of 5.77 m2/g and 0.017 cm3/g, respectively, while comparing with Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P200)/CH and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P2000)/CH catalysts. However, P1000 addition to active particles had a slight improvement on the specific surface area, average pore size, and total pore volume of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH-New while compared with Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH, which also benefits from the addition of P1000. The usage of the catalyst had a negative effect on its pore structure due to high bed temperature, but this effect is negligible. 3.3.3 XRD The crystal structure and composition of the catalysts were characterized by XRD and the results are shown in Fig. 5. It can be seen clearly in Fig. 5(a) that TiO2 coating significantly increased the crystal amounts from 6 to 11 due to good dispersion of active particles on the surface of TiO2 with a large specific surface area, and a crystal peak of TiO2 anatase (JCPDS PDF21–1272) (corresponding to (101) crystal face) at 25.5° significantly decreased after loaded Cu-Mn-Ce-O x active components, which could be related to the coating of active particles on the TiO2 surface. Different P x addition to TiO2 coating had no effect on crystal composition and amount, and MnO2 (JCPDS PDF 39–0375) and Ce4Ti9O24 (JCPDS PDF 49–1607) were main crystals among Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH and three Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P x )/CH catalysts. However, P x addition to TiO2 coating leads to a left shift of TiO2 peak in Fig. 5(b), which should be attributed to the lattice expanding of TiO2 by the effect of P x [23]. The larger the P x molecular weight, the more apparent the left shift of the TiO2 peak. Cu-Mn-Ce active components combined with Ti to form Cu4Ti3 and (Mn,Ti) alloy-phases and Ce4Ti9O24 oxide crystals in Fig. 5(a), and the left shift of their crystal peaks in Fig. 5(b) could also be due to the lattice expanding of TiO2. In Fig. 5(c), P x addition to active components made some changes to crystal composition and amounts, and CeO2, Cu2O, and CeTi21O38 crystals appeared and CuMn2O4 and Ce(Mn,Cu)6 crystals disappeared simultaneously, which could be related to the dispersion effect of P x on active components and its adhesion between active components and TiO2 coating. Furthermore, the change of crystal structure and composition must cause an effect on the catalytic activity of the catalyst, apparently. Based on Scherrer equation [24], the diameters of MnO2, Mn5O8, Mn3O4, Ce4Ti9O24, and CuO crystals on the surface of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH catalyst were calculated to be 62, 45, 33, 47, and 31 nm separately. Small crystal sizes indirectly confirm the high dispersion of active components. 3.3.4 XPS The XPS spectra of four catalysts, such as Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH, and CuMnCeO x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH, are illustrated in Fig. 6, and the data were fitted and shown on Table 3. Fig. 6(a) confirmed the presence of Cu, Mn, Ce, and O elements in all samples and the corresponding Ti element characteristic in three catalysts. Fig. 6(b) showed the coexistence of adsorbed oxygen (Oads) with a binding energy peak at 531.6 ± 0.2 eV and lattice oxygen (Olatt) with a binding energy peak at 529.5 ± 0.2 eV onto the four catalysts' surface [25], and content percentages of Oads and Olatt that shown on Table 3 indicated that Oads was main oxygen species and TiO2 coating and P1000 addition to the coating or active components both increased the Oads content to some degree. It speculates that Oads content is related to the small size and uniform dispersion of active particles that benefitting from large specific surface area of TiO2 coating and pore-forming effect and steric-hindrance effect of P1000. According to Fig. 3 and Table 3, the sequence of Oads content is positively correlated to the catalytic activity of four catalysts, which confirms that Oads was the main active oxygen in our study. In Fig. 6(c), the Cu 2p spectra of four catalysts consisted of Cu 2p1/2 (950.6 ∼ 954.3 eV) spin orbital peak, Cu 2p3/2 (932.5 ∼ 934.3 eV) spin orbital peak, and two oscillating satellite peaks around 962.1 eV and 942.5 eV, respectively. The former study [26] confirmed the Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 peaks contained both Cu2+ and Cu+, and two satellite peaks further verified the existence of Cu+ and Cu2+ [27]. Fig. 6(d) indicated that Mn2+ (640.8 ± 0.2 eV and 651.0 ± 0.5 eV), Mn3+ (641.9 ± 0.2 eV and 652.8 ± 0.3 eV), and Mn4+ (643.3 ± 0.2 eV and 654.2 ± 0.2 eV) coexisted in the Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 spin orbitals of four catalysts [28]. The content changes of Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+ that are seen in Table 3 showed that Mn2+ amounts decreased and Mn3+ amounts increased after P1000 addition to the coating and active components, and Mn4+ amounts fluctuated within 26 ∼ 32 %. Simultaneously, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH owned the highest Mn average valence of 3.00 among the four catalysts. High valence state Mn4+ plays an important role in catalyzing the VOCs' low-temperature oxidation [29–31], and intermediate valence state Mn3+ could promote electron transfer on the catalysts' surface to accelerate the redox reaction of VOCs. In Fig. 6(e), two valence states of Ce3+ and Ce4+ were confirmed to coexit in the Ce 3d spectra of four catalysts. The amounts of Ce3+ and Ce4+ had a little change in Table 3 after the coating of TiO2 and the addition of P1000, and Ce4+ content was approximately four times of Ce3+ content. Ce3+/Ce4+ owned a function of oxygen reservation and release, which is conducive to catalytic combustion of VOCs that proved by [32]. Ti 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 characteristic peaks of Ti4+ in TiO2 coating were shown at 463.5 ± 0.3 eV and 458.3 ± 0.2 eV binding energies in Fig. 6(f), respectively. The characteristic peaks shifted to lower binding energies after P1000 to TiO2 coating, indicating an increase of electron density or a decrease of ligand O concentration in the vicinity of Ti. It is consistent with the XRD results in Fig. 5(b). 3.4 Stability test The stabilities of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /CH, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH, and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH three catalysts via six consecutive cycles (each cycle of 2 hours) at 200 ℃ (bed temperature) under microwave heating were tested and shown in Fig. 7. It was clearly showed that the catalytic activity of the Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /CH catalyst decreased gradually and the removal efficiency of toluene reduced from 84 % to 52 % after six cycles. The catalytic activity of the Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH catalyst exhibited stable activity for the first three cycles, maintaining a toluene removal efficiency of 95 %, before slowly decreasing to 84 % after the sixth cycle. However, The catalytic activity of the Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH catalyst demonstrated the highest stability, with toluene removal efficiency remaining between 99 % and 91 % throughout all six cycles. The observed activity decline in the catalysts is likely due to high-temperature effects on the structure of active particles. The pore-forming and steric-hindrance effects of PEG in the Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH catalyst effectively mitigated structural changes in the active particles, contributing to its superior stability. 3.5 Degradation mechanism The degradation mechanism of toluene by microwave catalytic combustion and the effect of PEG addition on the structure of catalyst are explained in Fig. 8. Firstly, commercial CH carrier was washed by diluted nitric acid to remove impurities in the channels, and some Mg2+ and Al3+ ions on the surface. Then, titanium sol that added PEG was coated onto the carrier's surface by sol-gel method, and TiO2 particles adhered to the defective sites that left by Mg2+ and Al3+ ions. Simultaneously, a number of pores were formed by the thermal decomposition of PEG molecules after calcination, which effectively increased the specific surface area of the TiO2 coating. And then, the active components' precursor solution that added PEG was completely absorbed by the cyclic impregnation method, and active particles were generated on the surface of the TiO2 coating after calcination. Steric-hindrance effect of PEG with polyhydroxyl structure makes active particles more uniformly distribute on the coating's surface, and some pores exist among the active particles due to the pore-forming effect of PEG. Finally, hot spots [33] were generated under microwave irradiation due to the robust microwave-absorbing ability of active particles, and toluene was degraded on the hot spots' surface and ultimately mineralized to CO2 and H2O. Electron transfers among Mn4+/Mn3+/Mn2+, Cu2+/Cu+, and Ce4+/Ce3+ [34] can take place mainly due to their different electrode potentials, such as Mn4+ + Cu+ ↔ Mn3+ + Cu2+ and Mn2+ + Ce4+ ↔ Mn3+ + Ce3+ [35,36]. Metallic cations are easy to connect with toluene molecule and gaseous oxygen by chemical adsorption, and transfer their electrons to molecular oxygen. Furthermore, This electron transfer activates the adsorbed oxygen and significantly promotes the oxidation reaction of toluene in the process of microwave catalytic combustion. 4 Conclusions In summary, P x addition to the TiO2 coating and active components both improved the catalytic activity of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P x )/TiO2(P x )/CH catalysts effectively. P x increased the Zeta potential value and viscosity of titanium sol by increasing the repulsive force and cross-linking among the sol ions, which decreased the size of TiO2 particles and enhanced the adhesion of the coating on the CH's surface. Furthermore, P x addition also decreased the size of active particles by the steric-hindrance effect of its polyhydroxyl structure to make Cu-Mn-Ce-O x particles more uniformly distribute on the surface of the catalyst, and more active sites resulted in the increase of microwave-absorbing ability to some degree. For different molecular weights of P x , P1000 has an appropriate molecular chain length to keep excellent inter-particle interaction of titanium sol, therefore, the catalyst that added P1000 owned the best catalytic activity of toluene. P1000 addition, whether TiO2 coating or active components, both increased the specific surface area of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH catalyst that conducing to the dispersion of active particles and the adsorption of VOCs. The lattice expanding of the TiO2 occurred after the addition of P x that led to a left shift of TiO2 peak, and Cu-Mn-Ce active components combined with Ti to form Cu4Ti3 and (Mn,Ti) alloy-phases and Ce4Ti9O24 oxide crystals on the catalyst's surface. More Mn3+ produced after P1000 addition, and the oxygen reservation and release of Ce3+/Ce4+ simultaneously promote electron transfer and Oads activation on the catalysts' surface to accelerate the redox reaction of toluene. Ultimately, toluene was completely oxidized to CO2 and H2O on the surface of hot spots under microwave irradiation. CRediT authorship contribution statement Huang Sining: Data curation. coredata.dc:description: Adding polyethylene glycol (PEG) can lessen the shedding of coating and improve the dispersion of active particles for monolithic catalysts. In this study, a series of Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P x )/TiO2(P x )/CH catalysts were prepared with different PEG molecular weights (P x , x = 200, 1000, and 2000) to explore the effect of P x addition on the structure and activity of the catalysts in microwave catalytic combustion of toluene. The research showed that P x addition (1 wt% dosage to titanium sol) to coating reduced the particle size of titanium sol and decreased the shedding rate of TiO2 coating 0.9–0.93 %, and P x addition (3 wt% dosage to CH's water absorption) to active components further lessened the shedding rate of the catalysts 1.93–2.04 %. Under an initial toluene concentration of 1500 mg/m3 and a gas hourly space velocity of 2260 h−1, Cu-Mn-Ce-O x (P1000)/TiO2(P1000)/CH owned the highest catalytic activity and its complete removal temperature (TR100) and mineralization temperature (TM100) to toluene were 180℃ and 218℃, respectively, which were lower 33℃ and 16℃, 56℃ and 58℃ than Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2(P1000)/CH and Cu-Mn-Ce-O x /TiO2/CH catalysts separately, and its activity maintained steadily with toluene removal efficiencies of 99–91 % over 12 h. The improved activity is attributed to the uniform dispersion of active particles, larger specific surface area, and increased adsorbed oxygen, facilitated by pore-forming and steric-hindrance effects of P x . Electron transfer among Mn4+/Mn3+/Mn2+, Cu2+/Cu+, and Ce4+/Ce3+ promoted the oxidation of toluene under microwave irradiation. Therefore, the research provides technological support for developing transition metals-based catalysts for industrial VOC waste gas treatment.
